references: Meanwhile, we find the experimental settings are not unified to a certain degree. For example, some works (Jiang et al., 2022; Fang and Ye, 2022; Yang et al., 2022) neglect the Non-IID characteristic of FL. Therefore, we cover more general settings that approximate the diverse label noise scenarios in practice. We prepare Table 1 to better illustrate the differences (especially in the methodology and experimental settings) between our method and related works that we implement and evaluate in this study.

Baselines
For main experiments, we implement sixteen state-of-the-art methods (discussed in Section 2 and Table 1). Unless otherwise specified, most hyperparameters of these methods are configured favorably in line with the original literature. We refer to official open-source codes of these methods. For convenience, we clarify some important hyper-parameter settings as follows:

Datasets
In this study, we consider three types of label noise (detailedly discussed in Section 3.2) and conduct experiments on five datasets and their statistics are shown in Table 2. We normalize the images by the dataset’s overall mean and standard deviation (Nguyen et al., 2022). For data heterogeneity, we utilize Dirichlet distribution to distribute total data to different clients, where each client is assigned with training data partitioned from the Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter γ𝛾\gamma, where a lower γ𝛾\gamma indicates a higher Non-IID degree (Li et al., 2022a). We set γ𝛾\gamma to 1.01.01.0 and 0.50.50.5 to generate two Non-IID degree. For CIFAR-N datasets, we additionaly conduct experiments with IID partitioning, since it is less explored in previous works.

references: We list the experimental results of synthetic noisy datasets with manually injected noisy labels in Table 3 and Table 5. We generate two Non-IID settings along with four label noise scenarios as discussed in Section 3.2. For noisy CIFAR-10 datasets, we observe our FedELC achieves the overall best performance while keeping a good balance between the precision rate and the recall rate, while other methods mainly exhibit evidently higher precision rate than the recall rate. Under the higher label noise scenario (i.e. symmetric label noise across 0.0−0.80.00.80.0-0.8), FedLSR (Jiang et al., 2022) and Symmetric CE (Wang et al., 2019) have slight improvement over our FedELC in the aspect of the precision rate. We also find robust aggregation methods seem to be not effective considering all settings. For example, Krum (Blanchard et al., 2017) is mainly designed against the byzantine issue in FL, which only selects one robust enough client-side updated model as the next-round global model and it fails to absorb enough information from other clients.

Now we analyze the evaluation results from the datasets containing real-world human annotation label noise patterns. The experimental results are listed in Table 4 and Table 6. For the CIFAR-10-N dataset, we find our method FedELC shows stably better performance than other baseline methods. Comparing Table 4 and Table 3 for datasets with manual label noise, we find that comparing with the label noise issue caused by human-annotation errors, manual injected label noise exists as an harder challenge for learning with noisy labels since nearly all methods have evidently higher performance than all settings of manual-injected label noise settings.

We generate two Non-IID settings along with four label noise scenarios as discussed in Section 3.2. For noisy CIFAR-10 datasets, we observe our FedELC achieves the overall best performance while keeping a good balance between the precision rate and the recall rate, while other methods mainly exhibit evidently higher precision rate than the recall rate. Under the higher label noise scenario (i.e. symmetric label noise across 0.0−0.80.00.80.0-0.8), FedLSR (Jiang et al., 2022) and Symmetric CE (Wang et al., 2019) have slight improvement over our FedELC in the aspect of the precision rate. We also find robust aggregation methods seem to be not effective considering all settings. For example, Krum (Blanchard et al., 2017) is mainly designed against the byzantine issue in FL, which only selects one robust enough client-side updated model as the next-round global model and it fails to absorb enough information from other clients.

Ablation on the logit adjustment & model aggregation
We conduct ablation experiments in Table 7 by removing the logit adjustment technique (Menon et al., 2021) discussed in Eq. 4 and DA aggregation technique (Wu et al., 2023). The performance get degraded by removing each, which reflects the effectiveness of these incorporated techniques.

references:
For preprocessing, all images are resized to 224×224224224224\times 224 and normalized.
The global communication lasts for 40 rounds.
Results are shown in Table 8.
We additionally evaluate FedCorr (Xu et al., 2022) and ELR (Liu et al., 2020) following the open-source codes.
For #15, learning rate is fixed to 0.1 to achieve higher performance.
For Robust FL (Yang et al., 2022) and FedNoRo (Wu et al., 2023), warm-up period lasts 10 global rounds.
Experimental results verify combining the fine-grained noisy client identification and online end-to-end label correction, our method FedELC achieves more reliable performance against its counterparts without compromising the privacy. Robust FL shows higher performance in the complicated systematic label noise scenarios, which indicates the potential of utilizing the class-wise feature centroids as extra supervision to robustly regularize the model training (refer to Section 2.3). We can introduce similar ideas into our method to further enhance the robustness, which we leave for future directions.
